results.title: Strike in town
results.creator_credit: Leslie McFarlane, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
The threat of a strike nobody wants, but which everyone seems powerless to avert, lends suspense to this story of events leading to a deadlock in negotiations between the management and employees of a furniture factory. Staged against the background of a small one-industry town, this dramatisation shows the normal processes of collective bargaining common to Canadian industry today and how they affect a union, a company and a community.
(Award: Chicago.)

results.title: Strike
results.brief_description: At the time of “Strike”, his first film, Eisenstein was a director of the Proletkult Theatre, an organisation with a boldly original technique of acting which led him logically to the medium of the cinema. The film has little formal plot in the conventional sense; a characteristic brilliance of wit and image association here achieves an almost surrealistic intensity. The photography often achieves effects reminiscent of the ‘metaphysical objects’ school of painting.

results.title: Stride to glory: a history of African Americans in the Olympic Games
results.brief_description: For as long as there has been the Olympic Games there has been the participation of African Americans and the sporting arena has provided them with an important avenue for expression. This program traces some of the key achievements and milestones of athletes at the Olympics (both Winter and Summer Games): the first male and female medal recipients; first individual gold; first team event, as well as placing the success of groups and individuals into the wider context of their success in sport in general, especially in relation to boxing and basketball. Involvement throughout each game is mentioned, with emphasis placed on some of the names synonymous with African American athletes: George Pogue; Jim Thorpe; Alice Coachman; Mae Fagg; Arthur Ashe; Rafer Johnson; Anite De Frantz and Wilma Randolph to name a few.

results.title: Strictly white collar
results.creator_credit: Norman Savage and W.D. Scott & Co
results.brief_description: Shows the application of methods-time-measurement to office procedures. The object of methods study is to reduce movement to an absolute minimum consistent with maximum speed and efficiency by eliminating, simplifying combining movements and changing their sequences if necessary.

results.title: Strictly speaking (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Edwin Newman runs a group session to demonstrate common communication faults. Directives should be: clear, concise, concrete, creative, correct. Avoid: redundancy (repitition), jargon, “ising”, overuse and misuse of words.
Based on Edwin Newman’s books Strictly speaking, and A Civil tongue.

results.title: Strictly for kids
results.brief_description: An experimental film utilizing children’s drawings cut against a background of child-like sounds. We see signs on walls: “Help!”, “I am Mad!” and “I love You”, mixed with drawings of people, faces, the moon and the sun, fish, crabs and a sinking yacht. Music by Costas, tiles by Gus and camera by Fotis.

results.title: Strictly Come Dancing
results.brief_description: A dance competition where celebrities compete to be crowned the winner. Who is kicked out of the competition each week is decided by the judges scores and viewer votes. Are today’s celebrities fleet of foot or do they have two left feet?

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

results.title: Strictly Ballroom
results.brief_description: The hit of the Cannes Film Festival of 1992 is a spirited, allegorical musical about a young, competitive ballroom dancer who outrages his mother and the establishment by insisting on dancing his own provocative steps.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but they’re scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

results.description: The hit of the Cannes Film Festival of 1992 is a spirited, allegorical musical about a young, competitive ballroom dancer who outrages his mother and the “establishment” by insisting on dancing his own provocative steps and taking on a new ugly-duckling partner who blooms under his tutelage. Ballet dancer Paul Mercurio shot to fame with this film. He is partnered by Tara Morice and supported by Barry Otto, Gia Carides and Bill Hunter.

Ballet dancer Paul Mercurio shot to fame with this film. He is partnered by Tara Morice and supported by Barry Otto, Gia Carides and Bill Hunter.
